work.p: This manuscript was probably early notes toward the manuscript poem "Pictures," first published posthumously in 1925. That poem includes the following lines: "And here again, this picture tells a story of the Olympic games, / See you, the chariot races? See you, the boxers boxing, and the runners running?" and "This, again, is a Spanish bull-fight—see, the animal with bent head, fiercely advancing" (Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts, ed. Edward F. Grier [New York: New York University Press, 1984], 4:1298–1300). Part of "Pictures" was published as "My Picture-Gallery" in The American in October 1880 and later incorporated into Leaves of Grass.

This note may also relate to the images described in "Poem of Salutation," first published in the 1856 edition of Leaves of Grass and later retitled "Salut au Monde!" See in particular the following lines: "You citizen of Prague! you Roman! Napolitan! Greek! / You lithe matador in the arena at Seville!" (1856, p. 117).

a machine readable transcription

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: The poem proposed here is likely related to both "Pictures," a lengthy manuscript poem held at the Beinecke Library at Yale University that was probably written in the mid- to late-1850s, and "Poem of Salutation," first published in the 1856 edition of Leaves of Grass and later retitled "Salut au Monde!" Therefore, the date of this manuscript is probably before 1856.

body.note: Picture of one of the Greek games—wrestling, or the chariot-race, or running.
body.ab: Each verse presenting a picture of some characteristic scene, event, group, or personage—old or new, other countries or our own country.—
